loans.name: Urjinhand

texts.en:
Urjinhand, 49, is married and lives with her husband and two children in the Uvs province of Mongolia. Her husband works as an assistant for a car-repair workshop in the winter and does construction work in the summer time. Her son attends a college and her daughter goes to a local secondary school. 

Urjinhand began the retail trading of coal and firewood in 2003. In addition to her retail business, she operates a well to sell water to locals. She sells coal and firewood outside the well. A bag of coal costs 3,500-4,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) and wood costs 2,500-3,000 MNT. Her monthly income fluctuates between 100,000 to 200,000 MNT. 

She is a sociable and hardworking person and her family members support her business. She is requesting a loan of 500,000 MNT to purchase more coal and firewood for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more coal and firewood

loans.name: Khuth

texts.en:
Khuth S., 31, resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. S. sells meatballs and barbecue, earning an income of $5 per day. Her husband is a motorbike repairman, earning an income of $6 per day. 

Each month, the family has to spend $35 on food and $50 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase motorbike spare parts to resell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner. S. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: to buy motorbike spare parts to resell

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Danaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 47 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de condiments, de l’arachide, de la volaille et du bois de chauffe.                                                                                                                       
Les femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur premier prêt .RAMATOU C. compte acheter beaucoup de condiments au niveau du marché de Nangola avec les revendeurs. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement au village de Wakoro, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  25 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce de condiments.
texts.en:
The women of the group Danaya are all married and average 47 years of age and five children living in traditional extended families in the village of Wakoro, prefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another through ties of kinship, community, and friendship. And they do commerce in condiments, peanuts, poultry, and firewood. The group members are now on their first loan.

Ms. Ramatou C. intends to use her loan to buy a lot of condiments from retailers at the Nangola market. She makes her sales every day, accepting cash or credit from a customer base composed of women and men. 

Ramatou envisions making an average monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be used to make the loan payments and to help pay for societal ceremonies. The rest of the profits will be reinvested in her condiments business.

loans.use: to buy condiments

loans.name: Victor

texts.en: Victor B.'s main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. He is a 40-year-old single man from the village of Canabuan Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. Victor has been in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) every four month harvest season. In 2011, Victor joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Victor is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his first loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Simpol

texts.en: To make a living, Simpol B. plants and harvests rice for sale. He is 43 years old, married and has six school-aged children. They are from the village of Canabuan Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. Simpol has been in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 28,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) every harvest season. In 2011, Simpol joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his first loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Yanjmaa

texts.en: Yanjmaa, 40, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Uvs province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they have owned for the past five years. Her older daughter attends college and the other three children go to a local secondary school. Yanjmaa makes clothes at home. She began exporting her handmade clothes and other consumer goods to Russia in 1997. She has gained much experience by running her business and built a good reputation among her customers. Her business revenues are much more stable now. Her husband helps her with the business and they are planning to have their own stall at the local market in the future. She is a hardworking and honest person. She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 tugriks to purchase clothes and materials from China.

loans.use: to purchase clothes and materials.

loans.name: Benedetta

texts.en:
Benedetta N. is a married lady. Her husband is a businessman and they have three children, aged between four years old and six months old, whom they hope to educate to the university level. Her business is located by the roadside in Kitengela. She sell cereals such as beans, rice, green grams [mung beans], maize and others to local people. She has been in this business for five years now and has provided employment to one person. 

Benedetta says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is that there are other people in the area doing the same business as hers, so customers are not loyal as they are spoilt for choice. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 90,000 Kenyan shillings to add stock of cereals to grow her business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to expand to wholesale and later make it a supermarket. She also sees herself owning a plot of land where she will build their residential house. She describes herself as ambitious and business-oriented.

loans.use: to add stock of beans, rice and green grams [mung beans].

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 40 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font la restauration, le commerce de la volaille, du bétail, des poissons et des tubercules.                                                                                                                          
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire. 
MARIAM C. compte acheter du riz et condiments pour la restauration effectuée au marché lors des jours de foire à Wakoro, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de restauration.
texts.en:
The women of the group Djekafo are all married and average 40 years of age and four children living in traditional extended families in the village of Wakoro, prefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women know one another through ties of kinship, community, and friendship. They do commerce in poultry, livestock, fish, and tubers, and they work in food service. The group members are now on their second solidarity loan.

Ms. Mariam C. intends to use her loan to buy some rice and condiments for a restaurant at the marketplace on market days in Wakoro. She accepts cash or credit from a customer base composed of women and men.

Mariam envisions making an average monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA that will be used to make the loan payments and to help pay for societal ceremonies. The rest of the profits will be reinvested in her restaurant business.

loans.use: to buy restaurant provisions

loans.name: Dinah

texts.en: Dinah is a 36-year-old married woman with one child. She lives in Trinidad, Bohol with her family. Dinah has been in the business of raising hogs for a year. She plants to use her loan to purchase piglets and feed. She also owns a sari-sari store and plans to use part of the loan to buy additional merchandise to sell. In the future, Dinah hopes to have a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase piglets, feed and additional merchandise to sell.

loans.name: La Gloire De Dieu Group

texts.en: La Gloire De Dieu, meaning "The Glory of God", is a group of three women who all live in the same neighborhood of Calavi, on the outskirts of Cotonou, Benin's economic capital. They have agreed to support each other in business and loan repayments. This is their third loan through Alidé. Felicienne (with her hand raised in the photo) is in her 50s, and lives with her husband, Mason, and three of their five children, who have all been through school. For the past 22 years, she has run her stall selling foods, mainly wheat and pork meat. She intends to use this loan to purchase more stock of wheat and condiments for sauces. Her ambition is to expand the scale of her business and, as an entrepreneur, she believes her strength lies in her ability to manage a diversified business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of wheat and condiments.

loans.name: Horloo

texts.en: Horloo, 49, is widowed and lives with her son in Uvs province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they own. Her son attends a college. Horloo began sewing clothes in 2000. Her business has become more stable now. She works for the Social Care Center of the city and makes clothes by custom order in addition to her job. She likes to make good quality clothes as this attracts her customers. She is a hardworking and honest person who says, "I have a job but my salary is not enough to make my living. I make clothes to earn extra income in order to save some money for my son's future studies." She is requesting a loan of 150,000 tugriks to purchase textiles and cloth for her business.

loans.use: to purchase textiles and cloth.

loans.name: Djigui Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djigui, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 47 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de tubercules, de gâteaux, de condiments et de la volaille.                                                                                                                          
Les femmes du groupe Djigui sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les trois précédents.                                                                           
DJELIKA T. compte acheter beaucoup de tubercules avec les revendeurs grossistes venus de Dioïla. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place au village à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour faire face aux besoins personnels et de ses enfants.
texts.en: The members of the Djigui group, all married women, are on the average 47 years old, with five children, and all live in traditional extended families in the village of Wakoro, Dioila Prefecture, Koulikoro Region (the second administrative region of Mali). They know each other as relatives, neighbors, and friends. They retail yams, cakes, condiments and poultry. The Djigui group members are on their fourth solidarity loan, having duly repaid the three prior loans. Djelika Troare plans to buy a lot of yams from wholesalers coming from Diola. She sells daily in her village, out of her home and at the market, for cash and on credit, to a customer base composed of both women and men. She plans to achieve an average monthly income of 15,000 West African Francs, which will be used to provide for personal expenses for her and her children.

loans.use: Achat de tubercules

loans.name: Tamam

texts.en:
Tamam is a 50-year-old mother and wife. Tamam has a big family with two daughters and five sons. Shadi, Fatima, Mahmoud and Basima are college students, while Hamza, Karam and Sameera are school students. Tamam and her husband run a home products store in Dier Al-Balah in Gaza Strip. Tamam's sons help her run the store. Tamam took out a loan from FATEN to purchase a large number of items to enrich the variety they sell such as plates, table kits, pans, etc.

Tamam's son, Mahmoud, who helps run the store, is photographed instead of Tamam, since she is a conservative woman as are most of Gaza Strip inhabitants.

loans.use: to purchase home products and items to increase her profit.

loans.name: Kiribedda Savings And Credit Farmers Group-Mityana

texts.en: B. Said is 63 years old and is now 2 years down the road in his charcoal sales business in Bujeeru-Mityana. He says he began this business after moral support from one of his closest friends. Before that Said, who is married with 12 kids, was a farmer. Weekly, this business brings in 40,000 UGX profits and he says with this loan he is going to purchase more firewood to burn and make more charcoal. Said belongs to Kiribedda Savings and Credit Farmers Group-Mityana.

loans.use: to purchase more firewood to make more charcoal

loans.name: Wangnigni Group

texts.en:
The Wangnigni Group consists of 3 women who have known each other since they were young. They live in the Calavi district on the outskirts of Cotonou, Benin's economic center. This is their second loan with ALIDE, following successful past repayment.

Ginette (with her hand raised in the photo) is nearly 40 years old and lives with her husband, Gafari, and their 7 children, who are all schooled. For the past 3 years, Ginette has run her shop selling cosmetics supplies in Calavi. This loan will enable her to purchase additional stock from Tokpa, Cotonou's largest market, to resell at her store. She states her greatest strength as her managerial ability, and she hopes to grow her business into a large grocer.

loans.use: to purchase additional cosmetics stock

loans.name: Dieu Est Grand Group

texts.en:
The group "Dieu Est Grand", which means God Is Great, consists of 3 women who all live in the same neighborhood and go to the same church. They live in the Calavi district on the outskirts of Cotonou, Benin's economic center. This is their first loan through ALIDE, and they have agreed to support each others' businesses and loan repayments.

Eugenie (with her hand raised in the photo) was born in 1969 in Cotonou, and has lived in Calavi for the past 10 years. Her husband, Elyseé, works with the police, and they have 2 children who both go to school. For 14 years Eugenie has run her stall from her house, where she sells primarily cloth but also food. With this loan she will restock her supplies with the aim of growing her business. Her strongest points as an entrepreneur are her client management skills.

loans.use: to purchase more cloth for resale

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene N. is a married woman with five children who all attend school. For the past six years she has operated an open-air food stall. She sells such food as cooked beans, chapati and rice. Her potential customers are neighbors and passersby.

Irene decided to work with Yehu Microfinance because of its responsiveness to customer needs. She is requesting a second Kiva loan of 60,000 KES to increase her stock of food to sell, such as sacks of maize flour, rice, wheat flour, coconuts and charcoal. She dreams of expanding her business and becoming a big supplier in the future.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of maize flour, rice, wheat flour, coconuts and charcoal

loans.name: Kolaban Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kolaban, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 42 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de fruits, de sésame, de la volaille et font la restauration. Les femmes du groupe Kolaban sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire.                                                                                                                          
FOUNE T. compte acheter beaucoup de fruits avec les revendeurs du village et environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce de fruits.
texts.en:
The members of the Kolaban group are women, all married, are in average 42 years old, have an average of four children and live in traditional exlarged families in the village of Wakoro, Prefecture of Dioïla, in the Koulikoro Region (Second Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali).
They know one another through ties of family, neighborhood and friendship. They sell fruit, sesame, poultry and run some restaurant business. They are requesting their second loan. Foun T. plans to buy a big amount of fruit from local providers. She sells it every day at home and at the local market, cash and credit, to a customer base of men and women.
She expects to earn a monthly profit of 10 000F CFA, to be used to pay back the loan and to give a contribution for social activities, while the rest will be reinvested in her fruit selling business.

loans.use: to purchase fruit

loans.name: Nyamtseren

texts.en: Nyamtseren is 31 years old and lives with her parents and three children in Uvurhangay province of Mongolia. They live in a house on a small plot of land that they have owned since 2007. Nyamtseren began retail trading of consumer goods in 2006. She bought a big container with her business revenue in 2008, which she operates as a clothing shop. In the summertime, she sells clothing by travelling to the countryside by car. She has gained much business experience so far. She is trying to expand her business and increase her working capital. She is a hardworking person with initiative. She is requesting a loan of 3,500,000 tugriks to purchase more clothes for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes.

loans.name: Myassar

texts.en:
Myassar D. is the mother of four daughters and two sons. She is from Dier Al-Balah in Gaza Strip where her tailoring workshop is located. Myassar works in one of the rooms in her house. Myassar's sons and daughters are college and school students.

Myassar took out a loan from FATEN to purchase sewing machines that appears in the picture here with her son, Issa, as she is a religious woman. Myassar needs to increase her production and work harder as the workshop covers family and school expenses.

loans.use: to purchase sewing machines.

loans.name: Jesugnon Group

texts.en:
The Jesugnon group consists of 3 women who all live in the same neighborhood and work in the same market. This is their third loan with ALIDE, following successful past repayments.

Camille (with her hand raised in the photo) is in her 40's, and lives with her husband Alexis in the Calavi district on the outskirts of Cotonou, Benin's economic center. Together they have one child, who will begin his schooling when old enough.

For the past 7 years Camille has run her stall in Cotonou, where she sells chickens and vegetable oil. With this loan from ALIDE, she will purchase further stock for resale. Her aim is to grow her business. She says her enthusiasm is her greatest strength as an entrepreneur.

loans.use: to purchase chickens and vegetable oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase stock in the general store

loans.name: Oyunjargal

texts.en:
Oyunjargal is 29 years old and lives with her grandmother, 72 years old, in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that she bought in 2008 with her business revenues. 

Oyunjargal began selling consumer goods at a rented stall in 2000. Initially, she ran her business with her sister and they expanded their business very well. Her sister was responsible for purchasing and importing the goods from China, and Oyunjargal was in charge of sales. In 2009, her sister moved to Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia, and Oyunjargal began operating her retail trading business alone. Her current stall is located in a crowded local market. So far, she has gained enough experience and has built a good reputation among her customers. She goes to China once or twice a month depending on the sales. She is a polite and hardworking person. Oyunjargal is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to purchase clothing for her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothing

loans.name: Kototala Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kototala, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 43 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de poissons, de l’arachide, de gâteaux, du bois de chauffe et des parfums. Les femmes du groupe Kototala sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les deux précédents.                                                                                                                                                                                                    
SATOU B. compte acheter des poissons avec les grossistes de Nangola. Elle effectue ses ventes à la maison et au marché de Wakoro au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce de poissons.
texts.en:
The members of the Kototala group, all married women, are on the average 43 years old with 3 children, and all live in traditional extended families in the village of Wakoro, Dioila Prefecture, Koulikoro Region (the second administrative region of Mali). They know each other as relatives, neighbors and friends. They retail fish, peanuts, cakes, heating wood and perfumes. The Kototala group members are on their third solidarity loan, having duly prepaid their two prior loans.

Satou B. plans to purchase fish from wholesalers in Nangola. She sells out of her home and at the Wakoro market, for cash and on credit, to a customer base composed of both women and men. She plans to achieve an average monthly income of 10,000 West African Francs, which will be used to pay off the loan and cover her cost of participating in major social events, with the rest reinvested in her fish-selling business.

loans.use: to buy fish

loans.name: Safarmo

texts.ru: Назарова Сафармо проживает в районе Дангара. Возраст, 39 лет. Замужем, имеет 6 детей. Дети учатся в средней школе. Сама Сафармо имеет средне - специальное образование, товаровед. По специальности проработала 10 лет. На сегодняшний день она занимается торговлей на рынке. Она в основном продает детскую одежду. Этим видом деятельности занимается 7 лет. Кредит берет для приобретения сезонного товара.
texts.en: Safarmo N. lives in Dangara. She is 39 years old, married, and has six children. Her children go to high school. Safarmo has a vocational education as a retailer. She has worked in her specialty for ten years.  Today she is trades in the market. She basically sells children's clothes. She has been doing this work for seven years.  She is taking out a loan to buy seasonal goods.

loans.use: to buy seasonal goods for resale

loans.name: Laurence Claire's Group

texts.en:
Laurence, Nina and Cathérine all share the same house in the Segbeya district of Cotonou, Benin's economic centre. They have agreed to support each other in business and loan repayments. This is their fourth loan with Alidé following successful past repayments.

Laurence was born in 1973 and has lived in her current neighborhood for 20 years. She is married with three children, who have all been schooled. For eight years, she has run her stall selling traditional Akpan meals, and she hopes to use this loan to purchase more ingredients (in particular, maize, sugar and milk) to prepare these meals. Her ambition is to succeed in her business and buy her own land to build a house. She believes her greatest strength is her ability to satisfy customer demand.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients to prepare meals for sale.

loans.name: Jaime Sr.

texts.en:
Jaime Sr. A. is from the village of Canabuan Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 53 years old. Jaime Sr. is married and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Jaime Sr. owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Jaime Sr. has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 35,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Jaime Sr. joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jaime Sr. is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jaime Sr. from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, such as manure

loans.name: Antonia Castillo's Group

texts.en:
Antonia C. is from the town of Naguillan Sur, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 57 years old. Antonia is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Antonia is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Antonia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Antonia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Antonia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Antonia is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase hog feeds and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Antonia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase hog feeds and other supplies

loans.name: Laure's Group

texts.en:
Laure, Prisca, and Berthe are sisters-in-law and good friends, and have agreed to support each other through business and loan repayments. This is their first loan with ALIDE. They all live in the Irédé district of Cotonou, Benin's economic center.

Laure is the leader of the group (with her hand raised in the photo). She is in her 30's, and is married with two children who are both at school. For the past 8 years Laure has sold jewelry. She will use this loan to buy additional stock from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim is to increase her product range.

loans.use: to purchase jewelry items for resale

loans.name: Sinignessigui Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sinignessigui, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 43 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce du bétail, des condiments et de l’arachide.                                                               
Les femmes du groupe Sinignessigui sont à leur premier prêt solidaire. 
 DJENEBA T. compte acheter des chèvres et des moutons avec les peuls du village et les environnants, destinés pour être revendus aux clients venus d’ailleurs, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée essentiellement d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de bétail.
texts.en: The women of the Sinignessigui group, all married, are 43 years old and have 4 children on average, and all live in expanded traditional families in the Wakoro village, Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through parental, neighborhood and friendship ties.  They sell livestock, spices and peanuts.  The women of the Sinignessigui group are on their first group loan.  Djeneba T. plans to buy goats and sheep from the shepherds of the village and the surrounding areas, which she intends to resell to clients from elsewhere, for cash and credit, to a customer base composed mainly of men.  She plans to make an average monthly profit of 20,000 FCFA which will be used to make loan payments and contributions to social ceremonies, while the rest will be reinvested in her livestock business.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Widad

texts.en:
Widad is a mother of one daughter and five sons. Mustafa and Muhammad are university students while Mahmoud, Yousef, Ihab and Mayar are school students.

The family runs a women's clothing store that supports the family. Widad took out a loan from FATEN to purchase women's accessories and start selling them with the clothing, which will increase the profit and attract more customers.

Widad's son Muhammad is photographed instead of her, as she is a conservative woman and not comfortable having her picture posted on the web.

loans.use: to purchase women's accessories to sell with the clothes

loans.name: Pierrette's Group

texts.en:
Pierrette and Alice are sisters, and together they live with Leontine in the Adogleta district of Cotonou, Benin's economic center. This is their fifth loan through ALIDE following successful repayments in the past.

Pierrette was born in 1955 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital. She has lived in her current neighborhood for 12 years, all the while running her stall from her home, where she sells traditional meals. This loan will allow Pierrette to purchase the raw ingredients necessary to make these meals to sell from her stall.

Her ambition is to evolve her business and increase her personal savings. She believes she has the qualities necessary to greatly increase her customer base.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients to prepare meals

loans.name: Soro Yiriwa Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Soro Yiriwa, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 49 ans, 6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’habillements, de condiments, de savon des bijoux. Elles font aussi le maraîchage.                                                                                                                          
Les femmes du groupe Soro Yiriwa sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire. 
FANTA F. compte acheter des habillements de tout genre avec les grossistes de Bamako mensuellement. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché pendant les jours de foire, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  60 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en: The women of the Soro Yiriwa group, all married, are 49 years old and have 6 children on average, and all live in expanded traditional families in the Wakoro village, Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through parental, neighborhood and friendship ties. They sell clothing, spices, soaps and jewelry.  They also do market gardening.  The women of the Sinignessigui group are on their second group loan.  Fanta F. plans to buy clothing of all varieties from the wholesalers of Bamako each month.  She makes her daily sales from her home, as well as at the market on fair days, for cash and credit, to a customer base made up of men and women.  She plans to make an average monthly profit of 60,000 FCFA which will be used to make loan payments and contributions to social ceremonies, while the rest will be reinvested in her trade.

loans.use: to purchase clothing.

loans.name: Akuvi

texts.fr: Madame Akuvi a 35 ans. Elle est mariée et a 2 enfants. Pour participer au foyer, elle fait la vente des produits de quincaillerie. Elle a commencé en 1998 et s’approvisionne en gros au grand marché de Lomé. Ensuite elle revend en détail dans le quartier Bè à côté de l’institut la Colombe de Dieu. Elle sollicite un crédit pour se réapprovisionner.
texts.en: Madame Akuvi is 35 years old.  She is married and has 2 children.  To be involved in the household, she sells hardware products.  She began in 1998 and she stocks up wholesale at the large market of Lomé.  Then, she resells at retail in the Bè neighborhood next to the Institute of the Dove of God.  She is asking for a loan in order to restock.

loans.use: to purchase hardware.

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Isabel is 50 years old, married and has five children. She owns a sari-sari (variety) store located in Trinidad, Bohol. She sells various products such as noodles, detergent soap, etc. She also buys and resells bananas. She goes to the next town to sell bananas.

Isabel requested a loan to purchase bananas and other merchandise to sell. She hopes to have a bigger store in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bananas and other merchandise to sell

loans.name: Tsend-Ayush

texts.en: Tsend-Ayush, 38, is married and lives with his wife and four children in the Uvs province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they have owned for the past 12 years. Tsend-Ayush began his retail trading business in 2004. He sells stationery such as pencils, erasers, pincers, etc., and also sells clothes. His wife helps him with the business. They purchase clothes from China and sell them out of a stall, which they have rented for seven years so far. His current working capital exceeds 2,000,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT), including his inventory. He is a hardworking and sociable person. He is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase more stationery and clothes from China for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more stationery and clothes

loans.name: Cécile's Group

texts.en:
Cécile, Bev and Delphine are all part of the same family, and have agreed to support each other in their businesses and in loan repayments.

Cécile (with her hand raised in the photo) is the leader of the group. She is 45 years old and married to Michel, a driver. Together they have three children, who are all educated.

For the past 26 years Cécile has been a saleswoman from her stall outside her home. With this loan, she will purchase various stock items from Nigeria for resale. Her ambition is to grow her sales, and she cites her welcoming personality as her greatest strength as an entrepreneur.

loans.use: to purchase various home supplies for resale

loans.name: Alexandrine's Group

texts.en:
Alexandrine, Florence and Sonian all live together in the Segbeya district of Cotonou, Benin's economic center. They have agreed to support each other in their businesses and in loan repayments.

Alexandrine (with her hand raised in the photo) is the leader of the group. She is 34 years old and has lived in the neighborhood all of her life. She has a husband, Gabriel, and three children who are all at school.

For the past 10 years she has run a market stall at Tokpa, Benin's largest market. With this loan, she will buy additional stock of underwear for resale with the hope of growing her sales figures.

loans.use: to purchase new stock of underwear for resale

loans.name: Tseveldulam

texts.en: Tseveldulam, 48, is married and lives with her husband and a son in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they have owned for the past 15 years. They have a decent standard of living. Tseveldulam began retail trading of meat and meat products in 2000. She used to work as a salesperson until she started operating her own stall. She purchases meat from individuals and sells it at her stall. She has been operating this business continuously for many years. She is a hardworking and polite person. She is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) to purchase meat for her business.

loans.use: to purchase meat

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 32-year-old Lebanese divorced man. He is the father of one school-age child. He has owned a car repair shop since 2008, and has 10 years of experience working in the same occupation. He is the only income source for his family. He works hard to offer good living conditions to his child and to be able to pay his education fees. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase supplementary car spare parts. He is hoping to realize his business goals and be able to earn superior income. He is optimistic about his business development and willing to open a bigger store.

loans.use: to purchase supplementary car spare parts

loans.name: Dénise's Group

texts.en:
Dénise, Philomène, and Marguérite all live together in the Yenawa district of Cotonou, Benin's lagest city. They have agreed to support each other in their businesses and in loan repayments. This is their second loan through ALIDE following successful repayment of their first.

Dénise  (with her hand raised in the photo) is the leader of the group. She lives with her husband, Saloman, and their five children. She is 31 years old, and for the past seven years she has run a store selling various goods and foods. This loan will allow her to purchase additional potatoes, oil and toiletries to restock her store.

Her aim is to increase her sales, and she cites her ability to satisfy customers as her greatest strength.

loans.use: to restock various foods for resale

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Tiessiri, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 50 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce  d’articles divers.                                                                                                                        
Les femmes du groupe Tiessiri sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du mil, des bois de chauffe et des condiments.                                                                          
ROKIA C. compte acheter du mil, du bois de chauffe et de l’huile pour la préparation des galettes. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché pendant les jours de foire à Wakoro, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour faire face aux besoins personnels et de ses enfants.
texts.en: The women of the Tiessiri group, all married, are 50 years old and have 4 children on average, and all live in expanded traditional families in the Wakoro village, Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through parental, neighborhood and friendship ties.  They sell various products.  The women of the Tiessiri group are on their second group loan which will be used to buy millet, firewood, and spices.  Rokia C. expects to buy millet, firewood, and oil for the preparation of pancakes.  She makes her daily sales from her home, as well as at the market on the Wakoro fair days, for cash and credit, to a customer base made up of men and women.  She plans to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 FCFA which will be used to meet her personal needs and those of her children.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for a food-serving business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to enlarge and fix the family house

loans.name: Mémounatou

texts.en:
Mémounatou was born in 1976 in Djougon, Benin. She now lives in the Sémé-Podji district of Cotonou with her husband Marc and their three children. All of their children are being schooled.

For the past seven years, Mémounatou has sold old clothing and bits fabric from her stall in the Tokpa market, Benin's largest, situated at the heart of Cotonou. This is her second loan with ALIDE following successful repayment of her first, and will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from the Miessbo market nearby, which specializes in cloth. Her aim is to strengthen her business in the short term.

loans.use: to purchase tatters for resale

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Tiessiri, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41 ans, 3 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Wakoro, préfecture de Dioïla ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de savon, de l’arachide, de condiments et des tubercules.                                                                                                                          
Les femmes du groupe Tiessiri sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire. 
MARIAM B. compte acheter deux sacs de savon local avec les fabricants du village et les environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  70 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce de savon.
texts.en: The women of the Tiessiri group, all married, are 41 years old and have 3 children on average, and all live in expanded traditional families in the Wakoro village, Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through parental, neighborhood and friendship ties.  They sell soap, peanuts, spices and tubers.  The women of the Tiessiri group are on their fourth group loan.  Mariam B. expects to buy two bags of local soap from the producers of the village and surrounding areas.  She makes her sales from her home and at the market, for cash and credit, to a customer base made up of men and women.  She plans to make an average monthly profit of 70,000 FCFA which will be used to make loan payments and contributions to social ceremonies, while the rest will be reinvested in her soap business.

loans.use: to purchase soap.

loans.name: Oynihol

texts.ru: Рахимова Ойнихол проживает в районе Дангара. Ей 52 года. Она замужем, имеет 7 детей. Муж находится в России на заработках. Сама Ойнихол имеет среднее образование. После отъезда мужа ей пришлось работать, чтобы прокормить семью. Она уже 10 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. У нее имеется торговая точка, где она продает разные материалы. Кредит берет для покупки ткани и материалов.
texts.en: Oynihol R. lives in Dangara. She is 52 years old, married, and has seven children. Her husband is working in Russia. Oynihol has a high school education. After her husband left, she had to work very hard to support the family. She has been trading in the market for ten years. She has a shop where she sells different sewing goods. She is taking out a loan to buy fabric and sewing goods.

loans.use: to buy fabric and sewing goods

loans.name: Martine

texts.en:
Martine is 50 years old and now lives in the Sémé-Podji district with her husband Gabriel and their six children. Three of their children are still in their care. All of their children are schooled.

For the past 20 years, Martine has sold food from her stall outside her home. This is her second loan with ALIDE following successful first repayment. It will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim is to improve her credit eligibility.

loans.use: to purchase various foods & condiments to sell in her stall

loans.name: Pierrette

texts.en:
Pierrette was born in 1974 in Cotonou, Benin's largest city. She now lives in the Sémé-Podji district with her husband Gilbert and their three children. All of their children are schooled.

For the past 10 years, Pierrette has sold clothing and clothing scraps from her stall in the Tokpa market, Benin's largest market situated in the heart of Cotonou. This is her second loan with ALIDE following successful repayment of her first. It will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from the Missebo market, which specializes in clothing. Her aim is to grow her credit eligibility.

loans.use: to purchase used clothing and scraps

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David M. is a single man with one child who lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food. He has operated a printing shop business for the past four years, offering his services to town dwellers and passersby.

With the 40,000 KES he is requesting, David wants to purchase a printer for printing services to meet his customers’ demands. He decided to work with Yehu Microfinance because it has no legal requirements. David dreams of operating a internet cafe in the future and to expand his business and earn more income.

loans.use: To purchase a printer

loans.name: Germaine

texts.en:
Germaine is 39 years old and lives in the Sémé-Podji district of Cotonou with her husband Justin and their four children. All of their children are in school.

For the past eight years, Germaine has been a travelling saleswoman, selling bolts of cloth around her district. This is her fourth loan with ALIDE, following successful past repayments. With this loan, she will purchase more inventory of cloth in bulk from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim is to strengthen her business in the short term.

loans.use: To purchase bolts of cloth

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.en:
Elisabeth is 42 years old and lives in the Sémé-Podji district of Cotonou with her husband Arouna and their six children. All of their children are in school. 

For the past ten years Elisabeth has sold cloth and used clothing from her stall at Tokpa, Benin's largest market in the heart of Cotonou. This is her sixth loan with ALIDE, following successful past repayments. With this loan, she will purchase inventory from Missebo market, which specializes in cloth. Her aim is to strengthen her business in the short term.

loans.use: Purchasing used clothing and scraps

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth W. K. is thirty-nine years old. She is single and has two children aged fourteen and eight. Her business is located at a busy market in Nairobi city known as Gikomba. She owns a clothing sales shop in which she sells school uniforms to parents of school-going children. Besides selling ready made uniforms, she also sells materials for making the uniforms to parents and tailors. She has been in this business for fifteen years now and has managed to employ six people. 

She says that this business is profitable, and the major challenge she has is lack of hardworking employees who don't perform especially well during peak seasons. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 50,000 KES to add to her stock of school uniforms to grow her business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to grow her business and in the future to become a big supplier of school uniforms materials. She describes herself as aggressive and dedicated to her work.

loans.use: to add to her stock of school uniforms

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to improve the cafe by replacing the chairs and old items

loans.name: Affoussatou

texts.en:
Affoussatou is fifty years old and lives in the Sémé-Podji district with her husband Taofick and their three children. All of their children are schooled.
For the past 10 years Affoussatou has sold home products from her stall in the Abattoir district of Cotonou. This is her third loan with ALIDE following successful past repayments, and it will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim is to strengthen her business in the short term.

loans.use: to purchase stock of home products in bulk

loans.name: Faissatou

texts.en:
Faissatou is 43 years old and lives in the Sémé-Podji district with her husband Deen and their two children. Both of their children are schooled.
For the past 8 years Faissatou has sold condiments and spices from her stall in the Abattoir district of Cotonou. This is her third loan with ALIDE following successful past repayments, and will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim is to increase her credit limit through successful repayments.

loans.use: to purchase spices and condiments in bulk

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie is a married woman with two children. She is 35 years old and has been running a sari-sari store business for five years.

Melanie sells items like soft drinks, coffee, sugar and canned goods to the people in her community. She earns daily from the store. She is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP to buy more items to sell, such as soft drinks and canned goods.

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks, canned goods and other merchandise to resell

loans.name: Mangale

texts.en:
Mangale is a married man with seven children, all of whom attend school. His wife is a farmer and she contributes to the upbringing of their children from her earnings. They own a house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, he has operated a "boda boda" (motorcycle) business. His potential customers are neighbours and passersby. Mangale dreams of expanding his business in the future. He decided to work with Yehu after witnessing other members benefiting from the program. With the Kshs 20,000 he is requesting he wants to add to his savings and purchase another  motorcycle for transport "boda boda".

loans.use: To add to his savings and purchase another  motorcycle for transport.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old single man living with his parents and three siblings. He is from Lebanon. He has owned a barber shop since 2009. This young man learned this trade when he was too young. As is common in Lebanon, he helps his father with the family expenses. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to complete all the needed preparation to open a proper women's beauty salon. He hopes that with his new business, he will be able to attract more customers and offer them professional services.

loans.use: to complete all the needed preparation to open a proper women's beauty salon.

loans.name: Zaki

texts.en:
Zaki is a young man from Nablus; he is the father of one daughter and one son.  Zaki is a construction worker, specialized in fixing rooftops and in ceiling leakage problems.

Zaki took out a loan from FATEN to replace some of his old kit and purchase needed tools and items that help  him execute his work.

Zaki is photographed in the picture above.

loans.use: to purchase rooftop-repair tools

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase equipment for his shop

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Ганиев Рустам житель района Худжанд. Ему 50 лет. Он женат. Имеет одного ребенка. Образование-среднее. Он занимается производством сыра. Ему помогают жена и сын. Этим видом деятельности он занимается 10 лет. Кредит берет для покупки молока.
texts.en: Rustam G. resides in Khujand. He is 50 years old, married, and has one child. He has a vocational education.  He works making cheese.  He is helped by his wife and son. He has been doing this work for ten years.  He is taking out a loan to buy milk.

loans.use: to buy milk for making cheese

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to iImprove the small farm she plants with seasonal vegetables.

loans.name: Rukundo

texts.en: R. is 47 years old. He has four children between the ages of 7 months and 18 years. He sells green bananas and has done so for three years. This has helped him to feed and look after his family. R. is requesting a loan to buy more green bananas to sell.

loans.use: to buy more green bananas to sell

loans.name: Dalal

texts.en:
Dalal, who creates artistic handmade items, is from Marka- Amman. She is a 43-year-old widow and the mother of five.

Through Souk Ayyadi (an initiative of Tamweelcom which was ushered into existence to expand clients' promotional base)  Dalal found that she could increase her sales and expand her client base. This developed her business and helped her to assess the market needs.

Dalal is requesting a loan of 1,200 JOD to expand her artistic projects and improve her profitability. An aspiration of Dalal is to open her own shop where she can sell her products independently, which will improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: to expand her artistic projects and improve her profitability

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a married man with two children, one of whom attends school while the other one is still too young for school. His wife is a charcoal seller and she contributes to covering the family's basic needs. For the past seven years, Joseph has operated a carpentry business, selling from the shop to his neighbours. 

Joseph faces a major challenge of seasonality and theft in his business. He dreams of expanding and establishing more carpentry shops in the future. With the Kshs 20,000 he is requesting, he wants to purchase lumber for his carpentry business. He decided to join Yehu after witnessing other members who have benefited from the program.

loans.use: To purchase lumber for his carpentry business.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan M. is thirty years old and married. Her husband is a businessman and they have three children between the ages of thirteen and three. Her business is at the busy Gikomba market in Nairobi and is well known by the name Elsus Leather Shoes. She has been selling shoes to retailers and other local people for the last three years. Susan has been able to provide employment to three people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is debtors who refuse to pay as per the agreement. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 50,000 KES to buy leather for making shoes to grow her business and meet the demands of her customers. She wants to open another outlet and create employment opportunities. She also sees herself building a house for her family. She describes herself as social, aggressive and committed to her work.

loans.use: to buy leather for making shoes

loans.name: Badegna Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Badegna, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 36 ans, 3 enfants et vivent majoritairement dans des familles nucléaires  dans le village de Belenikoro, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de condiments, de savon et du charbon de bois. Les femmes du groupe Badegna sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire.                                                                                                                             
ASSAN D.  compte acheter des condiments avec les revendeurs du marché de Fana. Elle effectue ses ventes à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Bedegna group are all married, are on average 36 years old, and have three children.  They live mostly in nuclear families in the village of Belenikoro, in the Fana prefecture, in the region of Koulikoro (the second administrative region of the republic of Mali).
They know each other through family ties, as neighbors, and as friends.  They are in the business of selling condiments, soap, and charcoal.  The women of the Badegna group on are their second joint loan.
ASSAN D. plans to buy condiments from the vendors at the Fana market.   She makes her sales from home and at the market, for cash and on credit, to a clientele of men and women.
She foresees making an average monthly benefit of 10,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the interest on the loan, to make contributions to the costs of social ceremonies, and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy condiments

loans.name: Helwah

texts.en:
Helwah, who is an embroidery designer from Marka-Amman, is a 53-year-old married woman and the mother of five children.

Years ago, Helwah started her micro-business from home. Through her exceptional hard work and distinguishing talent, she was able to expand her business, and now she has five women who work with her.

Helwah is requesting a loan of 900 JOD to purchase raw materials, and she is looking forward to opening an embroidery center.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for her embroidery business

loans.name: Balimaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Balimaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 34 ans, 4 enfants et vivent majoritairement dans des familles nucléaires  dans le village de Belenikoro, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de charbon de bois, de l’arachide et font la restauration.  Les femmes du groupe Balimaya sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire                                                                                                                           
LALA B.  compte acheter du charbon de bois conditionné dans des sacs de 100 Kg avec les charbonniers de la ville et environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Balimaya group are all married, are on average 34 years old, and have four children.  They live mostly in nuclear families in the village of Belenikoro, in the Fana prefecture, in the region of Koulikoro (the second administrative region of the republic of Mali).
They know each other through family ties, as neighbors, and as friends.  They sell charcoal, peanuts and are in the restaurant business.  The women of the Balimaya group on are their second joint loan.
LALA B. plans to buy prepared charcoal in 100 kg sacks from the coal dealers in town and in neighboring areas.    She makes her daily sales from home and at the market, for cash and on credit, to a clientele of men and women.
She foresees making an average monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA which will be used to pay the interest on the loan, to make contributions to the costs of social ceremonies, and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy charcoal

loans.name: Mary Wanjiru

texts.en:
It's one year that Mary has been running a cereal shop in Kangemi market and her business is really doing well. She earns about KES. 99,000 in a month.  She is 34 years old, married to Francis, and a mother of two school-going children.    

She has never borrowed from any other MFI, and she learned about KADET LTD through a friend. She has applied for her second loan from KADET LTD, after successfully paying back her first loan in good time.  She plans to use the entire loan amount to purchase 10 sacks of beans and five sacks of rice for sale. 

Mary intends to use the anticipated profit to save and build rental houses, and  to grow the business, and to open another cereal shop to meet the demand in the marketplace in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more cereals, e.g., 10 sacks of beans and five sacks of rice.

loans.name: Balimaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Balimaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 33  ans, 3 enfants et vivent majoritairement dans des familles nucléaires dans le village de Madoudiarrabougou, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers.                                                                                                                             
Les femmes du groupe Balimaya sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des habillements, des condiments,  de l’indigo pour la teinture, de l’arachide et de la farine de blé.                                                                          
MAMA D. compte acheter des habillements avec les grossistes du marché de Fana hebdomadairement. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement au village, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Balimaya group are all married, are on average 33 years old, and have three children.  They live mostly in nuclear families in the village of Madoudiarrabougou, in the Fana prefecture, in the region of Koulikoro (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).
They know each other through family ties, as neighbors and as friends.  They sell various items. 
The women of the Balimaya group on are their second joint loan which will be used to buy clothing, condiments, indigo for dyeing, peanuts and wheat flour.
MAMA D. plans to buy clothing weekly from the wholesalers at the Fana market. She makes her sales daily in the village, for cash and on credit, to a clientele of men and women.
She foresees making an average monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA which will be used to pay off the loan.  The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy clothing

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita I. is from the village of Tinabalan, Gingoog City. She is 56 years old. Teresita is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she makes and sells snacks and other delicacies like rice, cassava and cheese cakes in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $285 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients and as working capital. 

Teresita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients like flour, eggs and milk. This will be her 6th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients like flour, eggs and milk

loans.name: Bendiya Group

texts.fr:
Les neuf femmes du groupe Bendiya sont toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 35 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles  traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Madoudiarrabougou, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’articles.                                                                                                                               
Les femmes du groupe Bendiya sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter de l’arachide, des condiments, des tubercules et des habits.                                                                         
TENIN S. compte acheter 300 Kg d’arachide avec les revendeurs du village. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place au village, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The nine women of the Bendiya group are all married, and average 35 years of age and three children. They live in extended traditional families in Madoudiarrabougou, a village in Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through bonds of kinship, neighborhood, and friendship. They sell various items and are now seeking their third group loan, to be used to buy peanuts, food condiments, yams and clothes.

TENIN S. intends to buy 300 kg of peanuts from resellers in the village. She sells daily on the village square, for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women. She intends to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 25'000 (ca US$ 50), to be used to repay the loan, while the remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy 300 kg of peanuts

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a young woman from Tulkarem; she is a mother of three sons. Fatima's husband is a Palestinian National Authority employee.

Fatima's house needs fixing after the winter season that caused damages to houses such as leakage and damaged paint. Fatima took a loan from FATEN for this purpose.

Fatima was photographed in FATEN's branch in Tulkarem.

loans.use: to fix and paint her house.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy G. is a 36-year-old lady and mother to a 16-year-old child. She sells second-hand clothes and specializes mainly in men’s trousers. She has been in this business for the last 11 years and makes a monthly profit of Kshs 20,000.

She is a new client in KADET and she has applied for her first loan which she plans to use to buy six bales of second-hand men’s trousers for resale. She hopes that she will make good profits which she will use to take care of her child and also expand her business.

Lucy dreams of operating her business on a large scale.

loans.use: to buy more bales of used clothes for resale.

loans.name: Suleiman

texts.en:
Suleiman is a married man with one child who attends school. His wife is a primary school teacher and she contributes to the family's basic needs. For the past two years, Suleiman has operated a garage business.  He operates from his shop, whereby his potential customers are motor vehicle operators. 

Suleiman not only depends on his garage business but he also operates a car wash business which contributes to his other source of livelihood and he is able to meet his family needs. He dreams of expanding the vehicle repair business and start a distributing company in the future.

With the Kshs 70,000 he is requesting he wants to purchase vehicles spare parts and lubricants. He decided to work with Yehu because of availability of sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To purchase vehicles spare parts and lubricants.

loans.name: Jemal

texts.en:
Jemal is 43 years old. He lives in the village of Ruisi, Kartli Region, with his family – his wife and two sons, who are 10 and 5 years old. The elder son goes to the secondary school. 

The main source of income for Jemal’s family comes from agricultural activities. In particular, they have six milk cows. They produce cheese and sell it to the retailers in the same village. Also the family owns an agricultural plot with the area of 3 ha, where cabbages and apple trees are grown. Most of the harvested fruits and vegetables are sold locally. The family is also involved in beekeeping; they have five beehives. Honey gathered from these beehives is sold locally. 

With the requested loan Jemal plans to purchase a tractor. He will use it to till his own plot, which will reduce his cost for tilling. On the other hand he will work with the tractor on neighbors’ plots and get additional income.  

Jemal plans to reinvest the profits in agriculture – purchasing additional plots of land and more beehives.

loans.use: to purchase a tractor.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Danaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 36 ans, 4 enfants et vivent majoritairement dans des familles   traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Belenikoro, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de beurre de karité, de condiments, de poissons, du savon et des parures. Les femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire.                                                                                                                              OUMOU C. compte acheter du beurre de karité avec les revendeurs du village. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à la maison et au marché, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 5 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Danaya group are all married, and average 36 years of age and four children. Most of them live in extended traditional families in Belenikoro, a village in Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They got acquainted through bonds of kinship, neighborhood, and friendship. They trade in shea butter, food condiments, fish, soaps, and fine accessories. The women of the Danaya group are seeking their second group loan. 

OUMOU C. intends to buy shea butter from resellers in the village. She sells daily at the her home and at the market, for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women.

She intends to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 5'000 (ca US$ 10) to be used to repay the loan, while the remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy shea butter

loans.name: Runelyn

texts.en:
Runelyn B. is from the village of Binakalan, Gingoog City. She is 25 years old. Runelyn is married and has three school-aged children. 

To make a living, Runelyn sells green and sweet bananas  in the local community. Runelyn has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Runelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Runelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Runelyn is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional green and yellow bananas to sell. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Runelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional green and yellow bananas to sell

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguisseme, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 34  ans, 3 enfants et vivent proportionnellement dans des familles nucléaires et  traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Belenikoro, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers. Les femmes du groupe Djiguisseme sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter de savons, beurre de karité, des habits, des chaussures et de la farine de blé.                                                                                                                                                                                                     
MARIAM C. compte acheter des savons de fabrication locale (Gabacourouni) avec les fabricants de la ville de Fana.  Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement au village, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 5 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguisseme group are all married, and average 34 years of age and three children. They live in nuclear and extended traditional families in Belenikoro, a village in the Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).
