She happens to have good entrepreneurial skills and the intuition of a true business lady. Her biggest pride is a piece of land that she bought recently on which to build the house of her dreams. Her monthly income is 7,600 soms and she believes this is not the limit. 

Dogdurkan, like other members of her team, treats this opportunity very responsibly and believes in repaying the loan on time without any violations. The purpose of the loan is to purchase more gasoline for resale at a higher price. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fuel

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is 50 years old and married with three children. Two of the children are in school. Marissa works very hard to provide for them.

Marissa runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell.

Marissa has been in this business for four years and sells a variety of items such as soft drinks, curls, cooking oil, candy, etc. 

In the future, Marissa would like to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.en:
Nicolas works hard to support his family. Nicolas is married and has a junk shop business in the Philippines.

Nicolas requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to purchase scrap metals and plastics.

Nicolas has been in this business for 25 years now and earns additional income from a general store.

In the future, Nicolas would like to send all his children to school.

loans.use: to purchase scrap metal and plastic

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza is a married woman with 2 children. She is 28 years old and has had a sari-sari (variety) store for 2 years. Riza sells items like sugar, noodles and canned goods. She usually earns about 4,000 PHP per month. Riza's husband is a fisherman. She helps him sell his catch at the market.

Riza is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy more items to sell such as noodles and canned goods. Riza hopes her business will grow. She also wishes that her children would go to a university some day.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell like noodles and canned goods

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa works hard to support her family. Elsa has a common-law husband and a computer gaming business in the Philippines.

Elsa requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy another set of computers.

Elsa has been in this business for five years.

In the future, Elsa would like to support the needs of the family.

loans.use: to purchase another set of computers

loans.name: Kaiyrsa's Group

texts.en:
Kaiyrsa S., 58, is the leader of this group. She lives in a small village, Kochkorka, known as “sleepy little Kyrgyz village” because of its quietness and security. Kaiyrsa is the mother of three sons, the youngest of whom is physically disabled and needs special treatment and care. The others work in the capital and live on their own. 

Kaiyrsa is a farmer and has various types of cattle. She received these assets in 1992 during times of privatization and, since then, has dramatically increased the number of livestock she owns. Nineteen years ago her start up capital was 10,000 soms, and now generates 5,000 soms a month. It has a small effect because of high inflation. 

She plans to use the loan from Kiva to buy another head of cattle and, hopefully, to resell it at a good price. The long-term goals of Kaiyrsa include making major repairs to her house and arranging the wedding ceremony for her son. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita works hard to support her family. Anecita is widowed and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Anecita requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase food and ingredients.

Anecita has been in this business for five years.

In the future, Anecita would like to send her child to school.

loans.use: to purchase food and ingredients to sell

loans.name: Zamira's Group

texts.en:
Zamira T., the 41-year-old leader of this group, resides in the small village of Kochkor, where the major activity of local residents is farming. Zamira is a high-school teacher, and with the help of her children she has time to run a cattle-breeding business which earns up to three-quarters of her family budget. Since starting the enterprise in the 1990s, the family has improved its financial state tremendously. However, their monthly income of 5000 soms is not enough to cover all costs. The loan from Kiva will be used to purchase additional livestock and broaden the business.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Milly

texts.en:
Milly Iga, who lives in the Sebina Zone neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda, is married and has eight children, one of whom is in school. Milly has had a tailoring business for six years, and she works seven days a week. She also sells paper as an additional source of income. Milly has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to purchase materials for sewing.

Milly's main business challenge is seasonality. Her goal is to expand her business and earn more profits to save money. Milly lives in a home that she rents; she does not have access to electricity or piped water.

loans.use: to buy more clothing materials for sewing

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy more fish for her fish vending business.

Stella has been in this business for three years and earns additional income from a trisikad transport business.

Stella has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of improving her business and sending her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Thimontée

texts.en:
Thimontée was born in 1964 in Porto-Novo, Benin's administrative capital. He now lives in the K. district with his wife, Honorine, and their four children.

For the past 23 years Thimontée has run a metal workshop outside his home. This is his second loan with ALIDE following successful repayment of the first. This new loan will allow him to purchase materials such as metal and solder for his customers’ needs.

Thimontée’s ambition is to grow his business by buying more equipment and to buy a motorbike for himself! He believes his greatest attributes are the care he takes in his work and his creative spirit.

loans.use: To purchase more metal and solder

loans.name: Arleen

texts.en:
Arleen is 37 years old and married with six children.

Arleen works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell.

Arleen has borrowed and paid back two loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from dried fish vending.

Arleen aspires to expand her business and to send her kids to school.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en:
Shamim K. is married and has six children, all of whom are in school. She also cares for her sister. Shamim lives in the Kisasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda, in a home that she owns; she does not have access to electricity or to piped water.

Shamim sells roasted maize. She has been in this business for seven years, and she works seven days out of every week. The main business challenge for Shamim is transportation.

Shamim has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to purchase more maize. Her goal is to do well in her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize for roasting

loans.name: Svet Sharshekeeva's Group

texts.en:
Svet S., 51, is the leader of this group. She is married and a mother of a nine-year-old daughter. She lives in the village of Kochkor. The couple managed to make furnishings for their house and purchase some electrical appliances.

Svet breeds various types of cattle and resells them in a local market to meat-packing firms. Svet and her husband are members of a local farming group that is actively involved in promoting agriculture and cattle breeding and defending the rights of farmers.

The loan from Kiva lenders will be spent on purchasing extra heads of cattle for further breeding and reselling. Svet is very thankful to lenders, since they will pull her family out of a very tough financial state.

This loan is being presented by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of its “3-Ps” concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow larger) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan—at: http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase more heads of cattle

loans.name: Kyabugimbi Intergrated Group-Bushenyi

texts.en: 54-year-old B. Eldard is affiliated to Kyabugimbi Intergrated group-Bushenyi. His main source of income for the past 20 years has been the sale of bicycle spare parts in Kyabugimbi Trading center. Eldard, who is happily married with 7 kids, is also a farmer who grows and sells bananas. He says this business generates around 60,000 shillings profit a week. With this loan, Eldard says he is going to purchase more bicycle spare parts to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more bicycle spare parts to resell

loans.name: Nortjie

texts.en:
Nortjie, 62, is a widow and the mother of six children. Her children, Leo, 41, Marcel, 39, Andre, 37, Yanti, 34, Reni, 32 and Yance,30, are all married. Nortjie lives with Yanti and her family in Oesapa Village. To make a living, Nortjie runs a photocopy business, which she's done since her husband passed away in 2009. This business helps her to generate an income. Nortjie is known as a strong woman for her age, as she still likes to work to earn her living despite her children being willing to support her. She enjoys spending her days running her business.

While Nortjie is happy with the business, she also dreams of running another business: a motorcycle wash service. She feels this business will improve her income as currently most people don't have time to wash their motorcycles and thus will require such a service. Nortjie is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 IDR to buy a diesel engine and other equipment to commence her new business. She hopes that TLM is willing to assist her in making her dream come true.

loans.use: to purchase a diesel engine and other equipment.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 48 and has 4 children, one of whom is old enough for school and is enrolled. Beatrice has a shop where she sells foodstuffs. She is requesting a loan to buy more foodstuffs. With the profits, she hopes to feed her family.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Kulyara's Group

texts.en:
Kulyara U., 52, is the leader of this group. She lives in Karabalta in the northern part of the country, population 38,700. She has been happy to live there and raise her kids but several years ago a severe tragedy hit her family. She was left a widow with 6 children to feed. All these years she has relied on her dairy business to provide her kids with at least the basic needs. Now, her children are grown up and live on their own; the youngest one is 16. 

Kulyara’s youngest son assists in processing milk and selling it wholesale in Bishkek market. In five years the number of dairy cows in her household has greatly increased. The business was started with initial capital of 2,000 soms and now the monthly returns reach twice that amount. 

Kylyara wants to give a worthwhile education to her youngest son and plans to increase her savings. Kulyara, along with the other members of the group, is in strong need of financial assistance because she would like to invest more in her business and get higher returns. 


          --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase milk

loans.name: Dansou

texts.en:
Dansou is 40 years old and lives in the Bodjrenou district of Porto-Novo, Benin's administrative capital. Together with his wife Felicité he looks after their four children, all of whom are schooled.

For the past 12 years Dansou has been making furniture from his workshop. This is his second loan with ALIDE following successful repayment of the first. This loan will allow him to acquire fresh timber to turn into furniture. His ambition is to open a large furniture shop. His greatest strengths as an entrepreneur are his welcoming nature and creative spirit.

loans.use: to purchase wood to build furniture

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora has a common-law husband and three children. One child is in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Leonora is 39 years old and has a trisikad transport business in the Philippines. Leonora requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to buy a bicycle and sidecar.

Leonora has been in this business for four years.  In the future, Leonora would like to have their own house and more trisikads.

loans.use: to purchase a bicycle and sidecar

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan B. lives in the Ntinda neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom are in school. She also cares for her two brothers. Susan has a business selling secondhand clothes. She has been in this business for three years and works six days a week. She also rents rooms and sells tap water as additional sources of income. Susan has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to purchase more secondhand women's and children's clothing.

The main business challenge for Susan is fluctuating rent for her business premises. Her goal is to own her own boutique. She lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent for her business premises and food.

loans.use: to buy more bales of secondhand clothes

loans.name: Massavi

texts.fr:
Madame Massavi gère comme activité génératrice de revenus, la vente de matériaux de constructions. Elle a commencé depuis 2008 et s’approvisionne au Ghana à Accra. Ensuite elle revend les matériaux dans le quartier Tokoin wuiti en face de CEG côté sud. Son stock de marchandises est en baisse, elle cherche à se réapprovisionner, raison pour laquelle elle sollicite un crédit.
Elle est mariée à un directeur de société et mère de 2 enfants, avec son commerce elle participe aux dépenses de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Massavi manages as an income generating business, the selling of construction materials. She has been in business since 2008 and purchases her inventory in Accra, Ghana. She then sells the materials in the Tokoin wuiti neighborhood in front of the CEG on the south side. Her inventory is low so she is asking for a loan in order to purchase more inventory.
She is married to the manager of a company and has two children. Her business helps pay the family expenses.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials

loans.name: Suzanne

texts.en: Suzanne is 41 years old and lives in the Lawole district of Porto-Novo, Benin's administrative capital. Together with her husband Pascal she looks after their four children, all of whom are schooled. For the past 10 years, Suzanne has sold meals from her stall outside her home. This is her fourth loan with Alidé, following successful past repayments. It will allow her to purchase stock in bulk from Adja, a large food market. Her aim is to diversify her business to new products.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients to prepare food for sale.

loans.name: Annalie

texts.en: Annalie is 33 years old and is a married woman with three children. The oldest child is 8 years old. Annalie is a farmer working in Banga, South Cotabato. She has been growing rice for nine years. Annalie works hard to provide her family with better living conditions. She also dreams for her children to go to a university and have bright futures. Annalie's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is currently in the business of selling beans and cooking oil. She is 30 years old, married to a policeman, and has two children who go to school. Grace borrowed a loan to stock more beans and cooking oil to sell. She hopes to expand with the extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: to stock more beans and cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Solange

texts.en:
Solange was born in 1976 in Porto-Novo, Benin's administrative capital. She now lives in the Lawole district with her husband, Stephane, and their only child, who is in education.

For the past year, Solange has sold refreshments from her home. This is her third loan with ALIDE following successful past repayments. It will allow her to purchase stock in bulk for resale. Her ambition is to buy her own plot of land. Her greatest attributes are her welcoming nature and her kindness.

loans.use: to purchase various drinks and refreshments for resale

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah N. lives in the Kisasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school. She also cares for her sister. 

Sarah has a business of selling maize (popcorn). She has been in this business for two years, and she works six days out of every week. Sarah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to purchase more maize and cooking oil.

The main business challenge for Sarah is transportation. Her goal is to do well in her business and prosper. Sarah lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: to buy more maize  and cooking oil

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is currently in a business of selling cooking oil, onions and bread. She is 37 years old and a widow with two children; only one child goes to school. 

She hopes to expand her business with the extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: to stock more cooking oil, onions and bread to sell

loans.name: Nazira

texts.ru:
Насыр кызы Назира родилась в селе Кожоке  (Ош область, Кыргызская Республика). Ей 42 года. Назира с супругом сегодня воспитывают троих замечательных детей. 
Назира родилась в простой семье, где была старшим ребенком и большую часть времени посвящала домашним хлопотам: присматривала за младшими братьями и сестрами, занималась домашней работой и небольшим хозяйством. Назира в детстве мечтала стать детским врачом, но, увы, жизнь заставила ее пойти совсем по иному пути - сегодня она говорит, что ее дочь обязательно станет хорошим врачом. В 18 лет Назиру выдали замуж и по кыргызской традиции, молодожены остались жить в родительском доме, так как муж Назиры был младшим сыном. Муж Назиры честно трудился в колхозе,  а она сама занималась домашней живностью и  к тому времени у них уже было 2 малышей.  К сожалению, земли в 4 сотки, выделенной на каждую семью было недостаточно для посадки и  затраты не покрывались полученным урожаем. В 2001 году, после похорон родителей, Назира с семей переехали в Чуйскую долину, в село Алексеевка. Здесь супруги купили дом с огородом и на остальные средства купили 2 дойных коров.  Средства от сдачи молока и урожая с огорода стали единственным источником пропитания и дохода для семьи Назиры. С тех пор прошло 10 лет, через многие испытания прошла семья, но благодаря упорству и трудолюбию, выбралась из тяжелого состояния. На сегодняшний день, в хозяйстве Назиры  есть 4 бычка на откорме, 1 дойная корова, также семья дополнительно занимается выращиванием лука. 
Назира берет кредит в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) для покупки двух бычков и овцематок. Это позволит Назире увеличить поголовье скота и расширить хозяйство. В будущем, Назира с мужем мечтают дать хорошее образование своим детям и  построить большой дом.
ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" предоставляет кредиты по линии Кива для социально-уязвимых слоев населения. ЗАО МФК "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" является одной из лидирующих Микрофинансовых организаций Кыргызстана. "Бай-Тушум и Партнеры" – это надежный финансовый партнер, осуществляющий вклад в развитие экономики Кыргызской Республики путем предоставления доступных микрофинансовых услуг в сельской местности и городах, способствующих созданию рабочих мест и отвечающий интересам своих клиентов и инвесторов.
texts.en:
Nazira N. K. was born in the village of Kozhoke (in the Osh area of the Kirghiz Republic). She is 42 years old. Nazira and her spouse are raising three remarkable children. Nazira was born into a simple family in which she was the eldest; therefore, she had many chores: looking after younger brothers and sisters, doing housework, and helping on the farm. As a child, Nazira dreamed of becoming a pediatrician, but, alas, life forced her onto another path.  However, today she says her daughter will absolutely become a doctor.  

When she was eighteen, Nazira got married.  By Kirghiz tradition, newly-married couples live in the parents’ house, and Nazira’s husband was a younger son.  Nazira’s husband worked hard on a collective farm; she worked taking care of the family’s livestock, and by then they already had two children. Unfortunately, the 400-square-meter plot of land allocated to each family was not sufficient to plant enough crops to turn a profit.  

In 2001, after her parents’ funeral, Nazira’s family moved to the Chuysky valley, into the village of Alekseyevka. Here the couple bought a house with a vegetable garden and bought two milk cows. Income from delivering milk and selling vegetables became Nazira’s family’s livelihood.  Ten years have passed since then, and the family has endured many trials, but thanks to persistence and diligence they are no longer in grave financial condition. Today, on their small farm, there are four calves being fattened, one milk cow, and the family is now cultivating onions.   Nazira is taking out a loan for 100,000 som (KGS) to buy two calves and some ewes. This will allow Nazira to increase her livestock and to expand the farm. In the future, Nazira and her husband dream of giving their children a good education and building a big house.  


Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to construct a dairy unit and expand his poultry farming capacity.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is currently in a business of selling charcoal. She is 50 years old. Mary is a widow with four children, all of whom go to school. 

Mary borrowed a loan to stock more charcoal to sell. She hopes to expand her business with extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: to stock more charcoal to sell

loans.name: United Youth Group-Bushenyi

texts.en:
M. Laban is a 49-year-old, level-headed stickler for hard work. This has in many ways played to his strength, especially as he oversees the running of his now 20-year-old liquor store business at his home in Bushenyi.

Laban is a happily married father of seven who says he took over this business after his father passed on. On the side, he also does some farming. 

He says this business generates 100,000 shillings weekly. He says with this loan, he is going to purchase more sweet bananas that he uses in the brewing of his liquor. 

Laban belongs to United Youth Group-Bushenyi.

loans.use: to purchase more sweet bananas that are used in making the liquor he sells

loans.name: Lilly

texts.en:
Lilly is currently in a business of selling green vegetables. She is 40 years old and married to a driver. She has four children and all of them go to school. 

Lilly borrowed a loan to stock more green vegetables to sell. She hopes to expand her business with the extra profits from her business in the future.

loans.use: to stock more green vegetables to sell

loans.name: Tsetsegmaa

texts.en:
Tsetsegmaa is 45 years old and lives with her three children in Ulaanbataar, the capital city of Mongolia. They all live together in small wooden house on their plot of land. 

Tsetsegmaa is left to raise her three children after her husband passed away in 2008. Her older daughter, Davaadulam, works at the state emergency department and her younger two sons are attending a university. Tsetsegmaa has operated a retail business for the last three years, selling pants and renting a stall at the Bumbugur market, the most crowded market in the city. 

Normally she buys her products from Ereen, the border city of China. Tsetsegmaa is providing her two sons' tuition fees. Therefore, she is trying to save some money by increasing her business profit. She is also one of our reliable customers. This time she is applying for a loan for the second time and wants to use it to increase her working capital by buying more pants and jackets.

loans.use: to increase her working capital by buying more pants from Ereen, the border city of China

loans.name: Forkland Group

texts.en:
Violeth W. is in her early 30s and is married with three children. She has been running a general store since 2005. She works from 6:00 a.m. to after midnight and is able to make a good monthly profit. 

This will be Violeth's third loan from Tujijenge Tanzani. She used the previous loans to increase the shop's inventory and also started selling second-hand shoes. She has paid back her loan successfully. She hopes for a loan to still increase on the shop's inventory. Her dream is to one day open a clothing shop.

Violeth will share this loan with her loan group, Forkland, which has a total of 25 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Violeth is first on the left.

loans.use: to increase the shop's inventory

loans.name: Kwembe Group

texts.en:
Prisca K., who is in her early 40s, is married with three children. She has a business of selling liquid soap and toilet disinfectant. She has been in this business for two years and works from 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. (just for six hours). She is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Prisca's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She wants a loan to buy ingredients for her business. She sells her products on order -- her customers ring and make orders and they either collect them or she delivers to them herself. Her dream is to one day have a factory where she can be able to make a big amount of stock and make it easy for customers to come in and out instead of her going door-to-door.

Prisca will share this loan with her loan group, Kwembe, which has a total of 24 new members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Prisca is first on the left, sitting on a chair.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her business

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona is 35 years old and is a married woman with 4 children. The oldest child is 16 years old while the youngest is only 5.

Chona is a farmer working in Banga, South Cotabato. She has been growing rice and corn for more than 10 years. Chona sells her harvest to her community. She has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. Chona works hard to provide for her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Valentine Group

texts.en:
Susan K., who is in her late thirties, is married with two children. She sells fabrics and sarongs door to door, and ice cubes at a place called Mwenge some kilometers from the city centre. She has been in this business for 6 months and works from 8.00am to 6.00pm daily. She is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Susan's second loan from Tujenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to buy more fabrics and sarongs and has repaid her loan successfully. She hopes for a loan to further increase the stock in her business.

Susan will share this loan with her loan group, "Valentine", which has a total of 16 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Susan is wearing a white blouse, 1st on the left.

loans.use: to increase stock

loans.name: Mediatrice

texts.en: Mediatrice is 40 years old and has 7 children aged 1 to 13 years old. Mediatrice has owned a boutique for 13 years. She is requesting a loan to buy additional inventory and, with the profits, she hopes to build a home for her family

loans.use: to buy more inventory

loans.name: Malila Group

texts.en:
Sabina D., who is in her mid-forties, is married with 6 children.  She has been running a fruit and vegetable business for two years. She works from 7.00am to 9.00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Sabina's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to increase stock and has repaid her loan successfully. She hopes for a loan to further increase stock. Her dream is to have a big place and to sell more different types of fruits.

Sabina will share this loan with her loan group, "Malila", which has a total of 18 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans,

In the picture, Sabina is wearing an orange dress, 1st on the right.

loans.use: to increase stock.

loans.name: Jalia

texts.en:
Jalia N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda.  She is single and has one child who is currently in school. Jalia has the business of a small hotel [restaurant] with cooked food, which she has had for 10 years.

To help expand her business, Jalia has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase chairs and saucepans for the hotel. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jalia hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her child. In the future, Jalia hopes to expand her business. 

Jalia is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by being able to improve on her way of living.

loans.use: to purchase chairs and saucepans.

loans.name: Phiona

texts.en:
Phiona N. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Phiona has a business of outside catering, which she has had for five years.

To help expand her business, Phiona has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase cooking oil and charcoal for making chapattis for sale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Phiona hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself.  In the future, Phiona hopes to become a lawyer after her studies.

Phiona is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil and charcoal for making chapattis for sale.

loans.name: Nike Air Group

texts.en:
Mohamed I. is in his late twenties and single. He has been a tailor for ten years. Working from 8am to 9pm daily, he is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Mohamed's fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzani. He used the previous loans to buy material and other items for his tailoring business and paid back the loans successfully. He hopes to use this loan to buy lining material, which he will use for dresses and tops. His dream is to one day buy a plot.

Mohamed will share this loan with his loan group "Nike Air". The group has 16 members, who hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

In the picture, Mohamed is the first on the right in the front.

loans.use: to buy lining material.

loans.name: Ben Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Ben, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 43 ans,  4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Tomba, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’habillements, de bétail et de condiments.                                                                                                                               
Les femmes du groupe Ben sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursé le premier.                                                                     FATOUMATA C. compte acheter des habits pour enfants et adultes avec les revendeurs de Dioïla. Elle effectue ses ventes au village, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Ben group are all married and average 43 years of age and four children. They all live in extended traditional families in Tomba, a village in Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through bonds of kinship, neighborhood and friendship. They trade in clothes, livestock and food condiments. The women of the Ben group are seeking their second group loan, after having repaid the first one without problems.

FATOUMATA C. intends to buy children's and adults' clothing from resellers in Dioïla. She sells in the village, for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women. She intends to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 15'000 (ca US$ 30) to be used to repay the loan and pay her contributions to social ceremonies, while the remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy children's and adults' clothing

loans.name: Donatha

texts.en: Donatha is 43 years old, married to a primary school teacher, and has 3 children. She has operated a shop where she sells beans and sorghum for 26 years. Donatha is requesting a loan to buy more sorghum and beans and, with the profits, she plans to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: to buy sorghum and beans for sale

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy N. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Prossy has a business of a small hotel [restaurant] that sells cooked food, which she has had for 10 years.

To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase and stock more food for the hotel for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Prossy hopes to generate greater profits and pay for her house rent and buy food for herself. In the future, Prossy hopes to build a house of her own.

Prossy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase and stock more food.

loans.name: Allen

texts.en:
Allen N. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Allen has a business of outside catering, which she has had for three years.

To help expand her business, Allen has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase cooking oil, baking flour and charcoal for making chapattis for sale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Allen hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Allen hopes to expand her business. 

Allen is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil, baking flour and charcoal for making chapattis for sale.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 50 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Tomba, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers.                                                                                                                        
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du savon, du riz, des condiments, des céréales et du bétail.                                                                       
AWA C. compte acheter deux sacs de savon avec les revendeurs au marché de Dioïla. Elle effectue ses ventes dans le village au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour couvrir ses propres dépenses et ceux de ses enfants.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi group are all married and average 50 years of age and three children. They all live in extended traditional families in Tomba, a village in Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through bonds of kinship, neighborhood and friendship. They trade in various products and are seeking their second group loan, to be used to buy soap, rice, food condiments, cereals, and livestock.

AWA C. intends to buy two sacks of soaps from resellers at the market in Dioïla. She sells in the village, for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women. She intends to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 40'000 (ca US$ 80), to be used to provide for herself and her children.

loans.use: to buy two sacks of soaps

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. None of her children is currently in school.   Annet has a business of making charcoal stoves, which she has had for 4 years.

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clay soil and iron sheets for making charcoal stoves for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Annet hopes to generate greater profits and pay for her house rent and buy food. In the future, Annet hopes to own a plot of land.

loans.use: to purchase more clay soil and iron sheets for making charcoal stoves for sale.

loans.name: Yelen Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Yelen, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 40 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Tomba, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Les femmes du groupe Yelen sont à leur premier prêt solidaire et font le commerce de condiments, du bétail et du savon.                                                                                                                               TAYE F. compte acheter des condiments avec les revendeurs au niveau de Dioïla. Elle effectue ses ventes au village au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Yelen group are all married and average 40 years of age and three children. They all live in extended traditional families in Tomba, a village in Fana sub-prefecture, Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through bonds of kinship, neighborhood and friendship. The women of the Yelen group are seeking their first group loan and trade in food condiments, livestock, and soap.

TAYE F. intends to buy food condiments from resellers in Dioïla. She sells in the village, for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women. She intends to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 15'000 (ca US$ 30), to be used to repay the loan and pay her contributions to social ceremonies, while the remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy food condiments

loans.name: Deme Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Deme, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne  43 ans, 6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Bekobougou, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers.                                                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Deme sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter du sésame, des  tubercules, de la farine de blé et du bétail                                                                        
ASSITAN C. compte acheter des sacs de sésame avec les revendeurs de la place. Elle effectue ses ventes au village, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Deme group are all married, and are on average 43 year-old with six children. They all live in traditional extended families in the village of Bekobougou, in the Fana sub-prefecture of the Koulikoro region (second administrative area of the Republic of Mali).
They met through relations of kinship, neighborhood, and friendship. They are in the retailing business for miscellaneous items.
This is the second group loan for the women of the Deme group; they will use it to purchase sesame, root vegetables, wheat flour, and cattle. ASSITAN C. is planning on purchasing bags of sesame seeds from local dealers. She sells at the village, and accepts immediate or deferred payment; her customer base comprises both men and women.
She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of FCFA20,000 which she will use to pay back her loan, pay her contributions to social ceremonies, with the remainder to be reinvested in her commercial activity.

loans.use: to purchase sesame

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Aisha has a business of selling charcoal, which she has had for one year. She also has a second business selling tap water.

To help expand her business, Aisha has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more charcoal for resale. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Aisha hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself. In the future, Aisha hopes to become a doctor.  

Aisha is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by enabling her to make money from her business to pay for her school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 35years old, married to a driver and has 4 children. Beatrice has a shop where she sells beans, and she also has a furnace for making bricks. A furnace is used to dry bricks so that they can be used to construct firm houses. And, the better you equip the furnace, the better quality bricks it makes! Beatrice has had these businesses for 6 years.

Beatrice is requesting a loan in order to reinvest in her businesses,she will buy beans and equip her furnace. With the profits, Beatrice plans to buy a plot of land on which to grow some crops.

loans.use: To buy beans and equip her furnace.

loans.name: Fati

texts.fr: Madame Fati est une dame dynamique et exerce comme activité la vente de céréales depuis 1990 au Marché de Kegué parmis les revendeuses de céréales. En effet elle s’approvisionne à Anié  et revient vendre à Lomé.  Son stock est en baisse raison pour laquelle elle demande un crédit pour acheter 5 sacs de maïs, 3 sacs de mil, 2 sacs d’haricot, et 2 sacs de sorgho. Elle est âgée de 40 ans et mère de 3 enfants. Avec son commerce elle participe financièrement aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en: Mrs. Fati is an energetic woman. Since 1990, she's been selling cereals at the Kegué market, among other cereals resellers. She gets her supplies in Anié, and comes back to Lomé to resell. Her stock is decreasing, this is why she's seeking a loan to buy 5 sacks of corn, 3 sacks of millet, 2 sacks of beans, and 2 sacks of sorghum. She's 40 years old and the mother of three children. Thanks to her business, she takes part financially in supporting the family.

loans.use: to buy 5 sacks of corn, 3 sacks of millet, 2 sacks of beans, and 2 sacks of sorghum

loans.name: Laîdou Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Laïdou, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 38 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Bekobougou, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers tels  les ustensiles de cuisine, les tubercules, de l’arachide et du bétail.                                                                                      
Les femmes du groupe Laïdou sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire.                                                                       MAGNE C. compte acheter des ustensiles de cuisine au marché de Dioïla le plus souvent. Elle effectue ses au village au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 18.000F CFA qui est utilisé généralement pour les dépenses familiales et particulièrement dans les dépenses personnelles.
texts.en:
The women of the Laïdou group are all married, average 38 years of age with four children, and all live in extended traditional families in the village of Bekobougou, in the sub-prefecture of Fana, in the Koulikoro region (the Republic of Mali's second administrative region). They met through relatives, neighbors and friends. They trade in various products, such as kitchen utensils, tubers, peanuts and livestock. 

The women of the Laïdou group are on their second group loan.

Magne C. is planning to buy kitchen utensils mainly at the market in Dioïla. She sells her products for cash and on credit to a customer base made up of men and women. She expects to make an average monthly profit of 18,000 FCFA which will be used generally for family expenses and particularly for her personal expenses.

loans.use: to purchase kitchen utensils

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Tiessiri, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 44 ans, 6 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Bekobougou, sous préfecture de Fana ; Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce. de beurre de karité, de galettes et du bétail.                                            .                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Tiessiri sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire.                                                                        ALIMA D. compte acheter des paniers de noix de karité qu’elle transforme en beurre de karité, ces noix sont achetées avec les vieilles du village. Après transformation, elle effectue ses travaux au village, et après le produit fini est vendu au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les échéances du prêt, payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the group Tiessiri are all married; on average, they are 44 years old, with six children each and live in traditional extended families in the village of Bekobougou, in the sub-prefecture of Fana, in the region of Koulikoro (second administrative region of the republic of Mali). They know each other through family ties, their neighborhoods and friendship. They sell shea butter, cakes and livestock. 

This will be the second group loan for the women of Tiessiri. ALIMA D. intends to buy baskets of shea nuts, which she will turn into shea butter;  she purchases these nuts from the elderly women of the village. After processing the nuts, Alima sell her product in town; the finished product will be sold for cash or credit to a customer base of men and women. She expects to earn a monthly profit of 20,000 CFA; she will use these earnings to pay for her loan, contribute to social ceremonies and she will invest the remainder of her earnings in her business.

loans.use: to purchase shea nuts

loans.name: Maroufatou

texts.fr: Mademoiselle Maroufatou fait le commerce de pagnes et divers produits de beauté. Elle a commencé son activité en 2008 et achète ses marchandises au grand marché de Lomé. Elle est ambulante et a employé une personne qui l’aide. Actuellement elle n’a pas assez de marchandises pour répondre à toutes les demandes. Ainsi elle sollicite un crédit au près de Wages pour acheter 15 pagnes Hitarget, 10 pagnes de Holland et de nouveaux produits de beauté. Elle a à charge un enfant et est née en 1987 à Lomé.  Avec cette activité, elle contribue financièrement aux dépenses de son enfant.
texts.en:
Ms. Maroufatou sells pagnes (colorful African cloth) and beauty products. She started her business in 2008, and gets her supplies at the Grand Market in Lomé. She's a door-to-door saleswoman, and has hired someone to help her.

At this time, she doesn't have enough products to meet demand. This is why she's seeking a loan from Kiva's partner, WAGES, to buy 15 "Hitarget" pagnes, 10 "Holland" pagnes, and beauty products.

She was born in 1987 in Lomé, and has one child to support. Thanks to this business, she takes part financially in supporting her child.

loans.use: to buy 25 pagnes (colorful African cloth) and beauty products

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 23 years old and has 2 children ages 4 and 2. Her children are not yet in school. Jacqueline is married to a restaurateur while she sells secondhand clothes.

Jacqueline is requesting a loan to buy additional secondhand clothes and with the profits she hopes to increase her capital.

loans.use: to buy secondhand clothes

loans.name: Ndef Leng Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité DEF LENG est créé depuis 1996, jour de l'ouverture du Banc Villageois de Baback qui l'abrite. Il est composé de 12 femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Elles sont regroupées par des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d'affinité. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame POTHE D. (debout à droite de la photo et levant la main) est responsable du groupe. Elle est agée de 59 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 09 enfants. 

Elle développe un petit commerce de légumes. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plus d'une dizain d'années. 

Son prêt lui permettra de financer un activité de vente de légumes tels des carottes, des choux, des navets, des oignons etc.

Avec les bénéfices qu'elle réalise elle parvient à inscrire ses enfants à l'école et à payer leurs fournitures scolaires. Aussi elle prend en charge la nourriture pour sa famille
texts.en:
Solidarity group DEF LENG was established in 1996, on the day the Baback Banc Villageois where it is housed was opened. It is composed of 12 women who live in the same neighborhood. They are grouped according to links of kinship, neighborhood or affinity. Their main business is retail.

Mrs. POTHE D. (standing on the right and raising her hand in the photograph) is the group leader. She's 59 years old, married, and the mother of nine children.

She's retailing vegetable, a business she's been running for more than ten years. Her loan will enable her to fund her business selling vegetables such as carrots, cabbages, turnips, onions, etc.

With her profits, she manages to enroll her children in school and pay their school supplies. She also pays for food for her family.

loans.use: to buy vegetables such as carrots, cabbages, turnip, onions, etc

loans.name: Djurabek

texts.en: Djurabek lives in Shahrituz, Tajikistan. He is married and the loving father of 4 children. He works very hard because he wants to expand his business. He has been in this business for 5 years. He sells foodstuffs such as pasta, sugar, coffee, sweets and others in the market. Djurabek is requesting a loan of 2,200 USD to purchase foodstuffs for his store. He is hoping to see his business expand and grow consistently. Djurabek has a cheerful personality which is always a positive factor in his work with his customers. He is willing to work really hard to see his business flourish in the future. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase foodstuffs for his store.

loans.name: Abdimitalip

texts.en:
Abdimitalip M., 41, is married and the father of five school-aged children, the youngest of whom is three. He works as a builder, helping his neighbors to reconstruct their houses, and is also engaged in cattle breeding and rice cultivation in order to support his family. Starting with initial capital of 15,000 KGS, he now manages to earn about 10,000 KGS a month from these activities.

Abdimitalip has applied for a loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase cattle and mineral fertilizer to manure land. It will allow him to multiply his cattle and broaden his business activities. In the future, he dreams of providing his children with a good education and building a big house for his family.

Bai-Tushum and Partners, one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan, uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas, leading to increased employment and meeting the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Zulfiya

texts.en: Zulfiza is the loving mother of 5 children. She has a grocery store in her own house where she sells daily need items such as clothes, shoes, perfume and other different foodstuffs. From childhood she was interested in trading. Her eldest daughter helps her in business. She has been in this business for 12 years. Zulfiya wants to get a loan of 9,000 Somoni for purchasing daily need items and for expanding her business. This loan will allow her to fulfill her goal and will increase her working capital. Successful, stable growth in Zulfiya's business will help provide a more secure future for her venture and family. loans.name: Manuchehr

texts.en: Manuchehr lives in Shahrituz, Tajikistan. From childhood he was interested in the farming business. He has worked in his farming business for 5 years and is very happy with the support of his friendly family. In his business, he gets help from his father, mother, brother and his sister. Manuchehr has been advised to use agricultural supplies such as fertilizers. This has lead to better results, which makes him very happy. He requests a loan of 12,000 Somoni. The loan will greatly improve his income and his family's living standards. loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy millet, niébé and corn

loans.name: Eshnazar

texts.en:
Eshnazar lives in Shahrituz, Tajikistan. He has five children. He and his oldest son breed cattle. He has been in this business for ten years. Eshnazar and his son work very hard because they want to make a good profit. During the month they visit the market four times to buy cattle. They feed the animals for a certain period and then sell them at a good profit. Eshnazar would like to get a loan 6500 Somoni to purchase more cattle. He wants to use the profit to support his family and expand his business.

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Teddy has a business selling tap water, which she has had for less than one year.

To help expand her business, Teddy has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to pay for the water bills. With the help of this loan from BRAC, Teddy hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, Teddy hopes to become a nursery teacher.  

Teddy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her manage to be self-employed and not relying on her parents.

loans.use: to purchase water for resale.

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Teddy has a business selling dried fish, which she has had for 9 years.         

To help expand her business, Teddy has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more dried fish for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Teddy hopes to generate greater profits and pay her own school fees.  

In the future, Teddy hopes to become a nurse.  Teddy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by being able to protect herself from HIV/ AIDS.

loans.use: to purchase more dried fish for resale.

loans.name: La Verite Group

texts.fr: Nyirarudodo  A.  est entrepreneur, leader du groupe d’affaire « La Vérité », âgée de 52 ans, mariée, mère de 3 enfants, tous ont leurs propres foyers.  Son conjoint est chômeur, sans emploi. La  cliente  Nyirarudodo  A. est vendeuse de fruits Mangues, oranges, avocats, etc. Elle vit de cette activité de fortune. Il fait longtemps  qu’elle exerce cette activité. Elle vient de réaliser  4 cycles en  bénéficiant des crédits de l’IMF Hekima pour  renforcer  son capital. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouveaux produis fruitiers (mangues, avocats, oranges, etc.).  En plus, elle ambitionne pérenniser  son entreprise, améliorer sa maison d’habitation et vivre paisiblement en paix avec ses enfants et ses  petits fils. La cliente Nyirarudodo  A.  remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  ses actions dédiées aux pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Le groupe « La Vérité » est constitué de 35 membres.
texts.en: Nyirarudodo  A. is an entrepreneur and leader of the group La Vérité (Truth).  She is 52 years old and has three children who all live on their own.  Her husband is unemployed. Nyirarudodo  A. sells fruits such as mangoes, avocados and oranges. She makes a living from this business. She has been in this business for a long time. She has just completed four rounds of loans with the micro-finance institution (MFI) Hekima which increased her capital. She will purchase an inventory of new fruits such as mangoes, avocados and oranges with the new loan.  Moreover, she hopes to make her business stable in the long term, make some home improvements and live peacefully with her children and grandchildren. Nyirarudodo  A. thanks the MFI Hekima for their committed work with poor women excluded from the traditional banking sector. The group La Vérité has 35 members.

loans.use: to purchase mangoes, avocados, oranges, etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Yuldoshboy

texts.en:
Yuldoshboy lives in Isfara, Tajikistan. He has three children. He has a truck which he uses to haul sand, rocks and other materials. After 20 years, Yuldoshboy has a stable business which generates sufficient income for him to improve his family's living conditions. Currently Yuldoshboy wants to expand his business, so he hopes to take a loan of 10000 Somoni to purchase another truck. Yuldoshboy thanks everyone who is supporting him and promises to repay the loan.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase a new truck

loans.name: Manjeri

texts.en:
Manjeri M. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Manjeri has a tailoring business, which she has had for one year.         

To help expand her business, Manjeri has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase materials for making clothes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Manjeri hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Manjeri hopes to build a house of her own.

 Manjeri is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by being able to improve her business that has added more capital.

loans.use: to purchase materials for making clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ilhom

texts.en:
Ilhom is married and the father of three children. His wife helps him in his business. Ilhom purchases goods from the neighboring region of Khujand and his wife sells them in the central market of Isfara. He is also interested in animal husbandry. Ilhom would like to borrow 10,000 Somoni to purchase a larger volume of food to expand his business, which in turn will help him improve his life.
